narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Attained knowledge about the film industry and film history in general and helped bring in the perspective from the film industry angle.
It was really interesting to engage with movies as a real art form rather than as a commercial object.

I learned how to analyze some of the most classic films of the modern era. I also learned how to connect the film to the historical context around it, and how everything in a film is carefully thought out to present to the audience
This course was a helpful overview of film history, creation, & analysis.
Basic and fundamental history of many aspects of cinema.

I learned a lot about how to analyze film as well as fundamental aspects of editing, cinematography, and mise-en-scene. I also gained knowledge of film history and contemporary debates over digital cameras versus film cameras.
basics of film studies

I learned the basics of film analysis and film theory. The class seemed to have three parts. First, we discussed what film physically is, and the medium itself (film reel versus digital). Next, we focused on the films and learned small-scale analysis terminology. We learned film terms like long shot, POV, and mise-en-scene. I loved watching the films and hearing Prof. MacKay's thoughts on each of them. Thirdly, we moved to larger-scale questions about film, like narrative, genre, and where the film industry is going now. I really feel like I have a great foundation in Film and Media Studies going forward.

This course taught me key concepts of film theory - film history, mise-en-scne, cinematography, etc. and introduced me to a great list of classic films that I probably wouldn't have watched otherwise.
an overview of the western film history; understanding the film jargons; basic intro to film analysis; understanding different genres; learning about great film theorists.
I developed a more well rounded background in film studies and learned important historical context that affected the development of film.
I developed a good foundational knowledge of film and media concepts.
Learned basic terminology in analyzing films as well as the theory explaining film from the beginning of film to present day analysis.
I learned the essentials of filmography and cinematography through taking this course. A strong overview of all of the different components that go into making a compelling film.
I learned fundamental skills about understanding how films are made, and how the many different strategies used in filmmaking can enhance the creative medium as a whole.

basic film analysis terminology
a look @ the basics
Knowledge of film vocab, editing/sound/other ways to think about film; I previously just thought about plot
Basic theory and techniques of film across the ages.

A broader outlook on film techniques and themes and how they influence each other. It opened my mind to how I view genre and cinematography by presenting me with films that bend the rules in both respects.
I learned to analyze films and think about them critically, tracking the use of certain filmmaking methods through film history.
The skills to study and analyze film
A very good introduction into films from many genres and disciplines and the tools to be able to view films critically.

The class provides students with the foundation for film analysis and it associated vocabulary. It also gives student the ability to put their analysis to practice by writing paper analyzing class films.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Online format resulted in a compounding of work- the recorded lectures on top of required films, on top of required readings, on top of live lecture was too much

Professor MacKay is a clear lecturer, but at times he is not very engaging. The subject matter is interesting, though, so it balances out. Additionally, the online format of watching the movies made it harder for people to focus on the film at hand, but that isn't anyone's fault really.
No weaknesses
The lectures were extremely clear, and the slides were helpful.
This course goes very deep into film theory (at least from my perspective as someone who has never studied film before), and it never feels boring.

Strengths: Professor MacKay is an awesome lecturer with an incredible wealth of of insights and knowledge. I learned so much from his analysis of the films, as well as his thoughts on film genre and history. Honestly, I would recommend any class with him. I think another strength of the class is that we watched so many cool films. The syllabus gives such a nice variety of popular movies you may have heard of (Citizen Kane, a Hitchcock movie, a Star Trek movie) and less conventional movies. One weakness of the class is that it's a lot of work to keep up with. 2 weekly lectures on Zoom, one additional recorded lecture on Panopto, watching the films themselves, readings, canvas discussion board, and section. I think it's well worth it though!!!!

Prof. MacKay and the TFs were great and made the lectures and section incredibly interesting. The written assignments and readings for the class were a lot drier and hard to get through, but they're manageable.

strength: a thorough overview of the film history; great choice of films and reading material
weakness: wish the class could be more engaging. wish more guidance were provided in terms of midterm paper and projects.

Strengths: Professor MacKay is very kind and passionate about the subject matter. To me, the lectures were actually a nice and relaxing break from constant work that allowed me to always learn something interesting on Mondays and Wednesdays. 
Weaknesses: None

Strengths: Professor Mackay is great along with the TA's that are selected.
Weaknesses: Four papers was a bit too much for this course but they were all fun to write.

I really enjoyed all texts and films I engaged with in the course. One suggestion would be to explore more on critical race theory and diversity in the industry, as it seems in the news that there is a new wave or approach to diversity in film production (thinking about ARRAY).

Well-structured course, with clear deadlines and a fun final project. Professor MacKay explains topics clearly and concisely, and offers additional learning through smaller, pre-recorded lectures on a given topic for that week. No weaknesses really, it's a great course.

I thought that a strength would be to allow for movie recommendations from the class, as I feel many kids in the class would give recommendations of movies that were similar to the content we were learning, and by taking their suggestions we could have an even broader selection of films to learn from.

strengths: nice and thoughtful lectures 
weaknesses: panopto lectures, 2 part midterm and 2-3 part final. double features could've been trimmed down in light of pandemic......

I did end up making my own copy of the syllabus including times for how long the films would last -- a minor thing, but I think including durations/page counts on the syllabus would help students' time management
Runs through the basics very well. Was always going to be tough in terms of watching the movies required for class -- just not as fun virtually as it would have been as group screenings on campus.
Great course. It could have been improved by using the media library in order to watch videos during lectures as opposed to afterwards.

This course does a good job of having students consider films not just as forms of entertainment, but also as art forms shaped by distinct voices. It caused me to begin to see films as messages conveyed within a certain context, whether the filmmaker is responding to world events or simply reflecting on their own inner thoughts.

Strengths: engaging, good instruction 

Weakness: ?
I really enjoyed this course, but at times, the lectures seemed a bit hard to follow, especially when going through the slides by themselves without the lecture.

As a virtual class it lost the group screening aspect which often add to the enjoyability of the class. Subsequently there was a lot more assigned work with readings, papers, and multiple films to watch in preparation for lectures.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The online format of the film watching was a bit odd, which was my main issue with the class in regards to differences caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the Professor MacKay and the TAs were very accommodating of various situations.
This was a great class presented virtually, no comments

Having the lectures recorded was extremely helpful, since it let me return to specific information after class. Additionally, when I had to miss class, I was able to catch up by watching the recordings. However, the amount of class content was excessive. In any given week, we would have to attend two lectures, watch additional pre-recorded lectures that could be up to 50 minutes, attend a 50 minute discussion section, watch and analyze up to two movies, and read from both the textbook and additional readings. There was not a single week in which I could keep up with this workload. This is part of a larger trend of professors assigning undue amounts of work during a pandemic, something which I do not understand the motivation behind, as this adjustment is hard enough.

I wish that we had been able to watch films in a theater, on a projector rather than alone in our rooms. I felt that there was really something lost by not having screenings. When I was watching the films, I found it very helpful to pause, rewind, or take breaks, although we were discouraged from doing so. Because of the nature of Zoom classes and screen fatigue, I would recommend that viewing habits like taking breaks and pausing be less discouraged so that people feel better about doing what they need to for their mental health. It just feels incredibly draining to watch Battleship Potemkin and The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari alone in a dark room during a pandemic. However, the class itself translated very well into Zoom and our section was lively and helpful.
I thought Zoom lectures were great. I think the panopto lectures were a bit long- and they made the work pile up.

strength: lectures and sections were generally fun and easy to follow
weakness: the class might feel a bit dry in virtual setting. For most of the time, I feel like I am watching & analyzing the films all by myself.
Really enjoyed the ability to watch lectures posted after set lecture time. For me, the closed captions enhanced my ability to synthesize topics we went over.
The extra Panopto lectures helped immensely in filling in some gaps that may have been created in lectures.
The ability to watch the required films on our own time as opposed to during a mandatory screening day was a huge help.
Panopto lectures were far too numerous. I don't think the students signed up to view extra hours of material every week.
All of my other courses had groupmes -- I don't know if I just wasn't added to this one or if there wasn't one, but having one for the whole class would be helpful for students to communicate
Definitely reduce the number of movies required to watch. Limited engagement with that.

Slideshows were well done. I would have loved to have seen the professor as they gave the lecture - would have been more engaging but Im not sure if that is possible with zoom. As stated above, use of the media library and breakout rooms during lecture would do well in the course.
Virtual all year. I thought the discussion sections went well through Zoom.

I think that it would have ben nice to feel more unified and present in the class especially considering that we were so separated due to the pandemic. However there isn't much that can be done about that. I think the class did a good job of making the materials accessible for the students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's a decent intro to film. As a stem student I knew I was a little out of my depth but I wasn't completely left behind and could more or less eek out a decent grade.
If you need an easy writing credit, go for it. If you want a very basic understanding of movies and their history, go for it. Otherwise, I'm not sure it's worth it.

Yes! Im not a film major and this is a great introductory film course. I really learned how to analyze films and how everything presented in films is meticulously thought out from the perspective of the director
I would recommend this course to any student interested in film academia or creation.

I would recommend this course to another student 100%. There is a hefty workload involved, and some of the films are not super enjoyable if you're not a film fanatic, but overall this course completely changed how I think about film.
would recommend to anyone looking for an introduction to film and media studies - makes you look at films differently!

YESSSS!!!!! If you have any interest in film, you should take it. But I would warn against taking this class if you want to just watch fun movies. Many of the films are not conventional, and take some patience to watch. I think it's absolutely worth it though. So yes if you have interest in film and cinema beyond watching conventionally entertaining movies, then ABSOLUTELY YES take it omg.

If you're the type of person who binge-watches video essays on films on YouTube or frequents r/movies on Reddit, this course is a great excuse to watch some incredible and important films from the last century that you may have otherwise missed. I was scared I'd find older movies boring and hard to get through, but I fell in love with almost every film on the list, from Hitchcock and Godard to Star Trek.

You can take this as a gut and skim all the readings and still learn a lot and do well. The guest lecturers were incredible as well.
yes, if you are interested in films and want to have a formal understanding of it.
Yes, if you are interested in film, this is a great way to get a very important baseline in your knowledge.

Yes! This course is great if you have a curiosity of film beyond just watching movies passively. This class is writing intensive though as you will have to write four papers (8-10 pages in length each).

I would definitely recommend this course because of all of the subjects it touches. From a student with no experience in film this allowed me to get a good taste of what is out there. I also appreciated the diversity initiatives the TFs and a guest lecturer did with the experimental films and animation, respectively. While there is more to expand on, the intention is something I appreciated in this course.
Yes- anyone who is interested in film studies should take this course!

I would recommend this class to another student if they are interested in film/film major as it provides key foundations for your journey ahead, but also to those not geared towards the film major because I think it provides you with an interesting take on the way the world is perceived through this creative medium.

This course serves as a great introduction to film studies, and therefore I would recommend this course to anyone even remotely interested in film. This is also a good course for those without a defined interest in film because this course succeeds in making the medium interesting and relevant.
I would recommend this course if there weren't as many panopto and if the final were less intense. the intensity of the final was jarring.
Yes! It was an engaging intro course, educational and accessible
On campus, yes. Virtually, think hard. You'll not be as engaged as you should be just because of the in-person nature of the class.
Absolutely. Great introduction to film analysis and its themes, insights, and challenges.
I would recommend this course to another student. I enjoyed watching the films each week and discussing them with my peers during section.
Yes. I enjoyed it
Highly recommend.  A great class to introduce people to the world of film and to learn how to view them critically.
